root.text:
Avalon is big American in every way except for the Toyota name.

Is it a full-size premium sedan? Is it a near-luxury sedan? Is it a domestic sedan, and if so, is it better slotted in against Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Chryslers, than imports?

These are legitimate questions raised when debating the Toyota Avalon. It is such an anomaly within the traditional Toyota stable that trying to pigeonhole or define it can be challenging.

The 2000 Toyota Avalon is the second generation of this disturbingly American sedan. With the car constructed exclusively in Kentucky, it can be argued that Avalon is American, if not a bona fide domestic. Its American credentials, however, don't end with its build site.

This is a large sedan engineered to butt heads with traditional American fare such as the Chrysler LHS, Buick LeSabre and yes, even the Ford Crown Victoria. When has an Asian manufacturer ever tried that? It is sort of plain on the outside, huge inside and has a truly boulevard ride. If you didn't know up front that Avalon was a Toyota, it probably wouldn't be your first, second or even third guess. This is a very American sedan in nearly every sense of the word.

While the styling has moved forward, the redesigned Avalon is very similar in size to its predecessor. Its length and wheelbase are unchanged. Both its height and width have been expanded by about an inch. Although it is wider and taller, Avalon's coefficient of drag has been reduced from 0.31 to 0.28. There is extra space inside too, but it is the rear seat passengers who have really benefited. There is substantially more legroom (2 inches) for rear seat passengers. However, front seat occupants find their legroom reduced by about the same amount.

Reallocating this space hasn't noticeably affected front-seat comfort but has done much to improve the quality of life in the rear. Because the seats have been raised a bit for improved visibility, the added exterior height doesn't translate into increased headroom. The extra width does offer more shoulder room. In other words, this was a spacious interior before and it has even more room now.

Powering Toyota Avalon is the same 3-liter V-6 found in the Lexus ES 300. In the Toyota Avalon it produces 210 horsepower and 220 foot-pounds of peak torque. Toyota has a reputation for building quiet, efficient, smooth-running power plants and the 3.0 V-6 is no exception.

While it doesn't blast off the line, it gathers itself up rather quickly and has plenty of reserve for higher-speed passing. A buttery four-speed automatic transmission conveys engine output to the front wheels. Reaching 60 mph from a standstill takes between eight and nine seconds. Fuel economy is about average for a V-6 in this weight class with a rating of 21 in the city and 29 on the highway.

Toyota Avalon rides atop a fully independent suspension. Although some cornering crispness has been sacrificed for the remarkably pleasant ride, steering response is immediate. Disc brakes on all four corners rein in the Toyota Avalon. Anti-lock brakes are standard.

Highlights of the interior are the wonderfully supportive seats, a variety of storage cubbies and the user-friendly instrument panel. The dashboard has been moved forward a few inches, creating a more spacious feeling. This is a more interesting interior when configured for five passengers than six. The shifter moves from the steering column to the center console, and the front seats become buckets rather than a bench.

Placed above the ventilation system controls, the audio controls are simple to operate. A rather large blue screen dominates the top center of the dashboard, providing everything from the time and date to how many miles worth of fuel remains. The trunk is large and will ingest a volume of cargo.

Quietness is also a Toyota trademark, and Avalon is certainly that. In fact, from inside Avalon's cabin you may be hard pressed to distinguish this sedan from its upscale Lexus brethren.

The base price of the Toyota Avalon XLS is $29,755 (the XL retails for $25,195). Standard features not already mentioned include dual front air bags, dual front side-impact air bags, height-adjustable front shoulder belts, daytime running lamps, dual-power outboard mirrors, 16-inch alloy wheels, cruise control, an information center, an outside temperature gauge, variable intermittent wipers, a seven-speaker JBL AM-FM stereo cassette-CD player, dual-zone automatic climate control, a leather-wrapped tilt steering wheel, power windows and door locks, keyless remote entry and auto on-off headlamps.

My test Toyota Avalon XLS also had power moonroof ($910), vehicle stability control ($850), and the leather package ($1,625) with leather seats, upgraded JBL audio system with six-disc in-dash CD changer, memory for driver's seat and outboard mirrors, and upgraded wheels. Adding the $485 delivery charge brought the price as tested to $33,625.

Heaps, Russ
The Washington Times
March 3, 2000
